title: Muhyiddin Yassin
text:
<a href="Order%20of%20Loyalty%20to%20the%20Crown%20of%20Malaysia">Tan Sri</a> <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Crown%20of%20Johor">Dato'</a> <a href="Hajji">Haji</a> Mahiaddin bin Md. Yasin (; born 15 May 1947), familiarly known as Muhyiddin bin Mohd. Yassin (; ), is a <a href="Malaysian%20people">Malaysian</a> <a href="politician">politician</a> who served as the eighth <a href="prime%20minister%20of%20Malaysia">prime minister of Malaysia</a> from March 2020 to August 2021. Appointed as premier amid a <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20Malaysian%20political%20crisis">political crisis</a>, Muhyiddin served for 17 months and resigned after losing parliamentary support, making him the shortest-serving prime minister in Malaysian history.
Muhyiddin grew up in the state of <a href="Johor">Johor</a> and joined the state <a href="public%20service">public service</a> after graduating from <a href="University%20of%20Malaya">University of Malaya</a> (UM). He assumed management positions at various <a href="state-owned%20companies">state-owned companies</a>. In 1978, he was elected as the <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">Member of Parliament</a> for <a href="Pagoh%20%28federal%20constituency%29">Pagoh</a>. During this term, he was appointed <a href="List%20of%20Parliamentary%20Secretaries%20of%20Malaysia">parliamentary secretary</a> to the <a href="Minister%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28Malaysia%29">minister of foreign affairs</a>, <a href="Second%20Mahathir%20cabinet%23Deputy%20ministers">deputy minister of federal territories</a> and later <a href="Second%20Mahathir%20cabinet%23Composition%20before%20cabinet%20dissolution">deputy minister of trade and industry</a>. As the <a href="Johor">Johor</a> <a href="United%20Malays%20National%20Organisation">UMNO</a> chief, he was the state's <a href="Menteri%20Besar%20of%20Johor">Menteri Besar</a> from 1986 to 1995. He returned to federal politics <a href="1995%20Malaysian%20general%20election">in 1995</a>. He was appointed to the <a href="Cabinet%20of%20Malaysia">Cabinet</a> as <a href="Minister%20of%20Youth%20and%20Sports%20%28Malaysia%29">Minister of Youth and Sports</a>. He was appointed <a href="Minister%20of%20Domestic%20Trade%20and%20Consumer%20Affairs%20%28Malaysia%29">Minister of Domestic Trade and Consumer Affairs</a> after the <a href="1999%20Malaysian%20general%20election">1999 general election</a> and became a vice president of UMNO in 2000. Under the premiership of <a href="Abdullah%20Ahmad%20Badawi">Abdullah Ahmad Badawi</a>, Muhyiddin served as <a href="Minister%20of%20Agriculture%20and%20Agro-based%20Industry">Minister of Agriculture and Agro-based Industry</a> from 2004 to 2008, and then as <a href="Ministry%20of%20International%20Trade%20and%20Industry%20%28Malaysia%29">Minister of International Trade and Industry</a> from 2008 to 2009.
In 2008, he contested and won the UMNO deputy presidency and was appointed <a href="Deputy%20Prime%20Minister%20of%20Malaysia">Deputy Prime Minister</a> and <a href="Minister%20of%20Education%20%28Malaysia%29">Minister of Education</a> by Prime Minister <a href="Najib%20Razak">Najib Razak</a> in 2009. As <a href="Minister%20of%20Education%20%28Malaysia%29">Minister of Education</a>, Muhyiddin ended the use of English as the medium of instruction for science and mathematics in public schools. He also attracted controversy after describing himself as "<a href="Ketuanan%20Melayu">Malay first</a>" when challenged by the <a href="Opposition%20%28Malaysia%29">Opposition</a> to pronounce himself as "<a href="Malaysian%20Malaysia">Malaysian first</a>". Muhyiddin was a vocal critical of his government and party over the <a href="1Malaysia%20Development%20Berhad%20scandal">1MDB scandal</a>; as a result, he was dropped from his position during Najib's mid-term cabinet <a href="reshuffle">reshuffle</a> in July 2015, marking the first incumbent UMNO deputy president to be left out of the president's cabinet. In June 2016, he was expelled from UMNO.
He founded the political party <a href="Malaysian%20United%20Indigenous%20Party">Malaysian United Indigenous Party</a> (BERSATU) in 2016. He returned to the <a href="Seventh%20Mahathir%20cabinet">cabinet</a> after his coalition of parties <a href="Pakatan%20Harapan">Pakatan Harapan</a> won the <a href="2018%20Malaysian%20general%20election">2018 Malaysian general election</a>. In February 2020, BERSATU withdrew from Pakatan Harapan, culminating in a <a href="2020%20Malaysian%20political%20crisis">political crisis</a> as the coalition lost its majority in the <a href="Dewan%20Rakyat">Dewan Rakyat</a>. Following Prime Minister <a href="Mahathir%20Mohamad">Mahathir Mohamad</a>'s subsequent resignation, Muhyiddin successfully formed new coalition <a href="Perikatan%20Nasional">Perikatan Nasional</a> by receiving support from enough MPs to form a <a href="Muhyiddin%20cabinet">majority government</a>, and was appointed Prime Minister on 1 March.
Much of his premiership was overseeing Malaysia's response to the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20Malaysia">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, which became a major crisis shortly after he took office. This included enacting several iterations of the <a href="Malaysian%20movement%20control%20order">Movement Control Order (MCO)</a>, a <a href="COVID-19%20vaccination%20in%20Malaysia">vaccination programme</a> and declaring a <a href="2021%20Malaysian%20state%20of%20emergency">2021 state of emergency</a>, where parliament and elections were suspended. Although his government's initial response was praised by the <a href="World%20Health%20Organization">WHO</a> and had high local approval ratings, the worsening of the COVID-19 crisis in 2021 attracted criticism and <a href="Impact%20of%20the%20COVID-19%20pandemic%20on%20politics%20in%20Malaysia">destablised the coalition</a>. Major coalition party <a href="United%20Malays%20National%20Organisation">UMNO</a> withdrew support for Muhyiddin and called for his resignation, in a continuation of the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20Malaysian%20political%20crisis">country's political crisis</a>. On 16 August 2021, he resigned after attempts to regain support from MPs were unsuccessful. He remained <a href="Caretaker%20government">caretaker Prime Minister</a> until his replacement <a href="Ismail%20Sabri%20Yaakob">Ismail Sabri Yaakob</a> was selected on 20 August 2021.
Early life.
Muhyiddin was born as Mahiaddin bin Md. Yasin in <a href="Muar%20%28town%29">Muar</a>, Johor, Malaysia. His father, <a href="Hajji">Haji</a> Muhammad Yassin bin Muhammad, was a <a href="Malaysian%20Malays">Malay</a> of <a href="Bugis%20people">Bugis</a> descent. Muhammad Yassin was an <a href="Islamic">Islamic</a> theologian and <a href="cleric">cleric</a> based in <a href="Bandar%20Maharani">Bandar Maharani</a>, Muar, Johor, while his mother, Hajjah Khadijah binti Kassim, was a <a href="Malaysian%20Malays">Malay</a> of <a href="Javanese%20people">Javanese</a> descent.
Muhyiddin received his primary education at Sekolah Kebangsaan Maharani, Muar, Johor, and Sekolah Kebangsaan Ismail, Muar, Johor. He received his secondary education at the Muar High School, Johor. Subsequently, he attended the <a href="University%20of%20Malaya">University of Malaya</a>, Kuala Lumpur. He received <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> (BA) in <a href="Economics">Economics</a> and <a href="Malayness">Malay studies</a> in 1971.
Early career.
After completing his studies, Muhyiddin joined the Johor state public service as the assistant secretary of training and scholarship. In 1974, he was appointed the assistant district officer (ADO) of <a href="Muar%20District">Muar</a>. He left the civil service to join the corporate sector in the Johor State Economic Development Corporation (PKENJ), managing its subsidiary companies like Sergam Berhad as managing director (1974–1977), Equity Mal (Johore) Sdn Bhd as Director (1974–1978), Sri Saujana Berhad as managing director (1974–1978) and SGS Ates (M) Sdn Bhd as <a href="Human%20Resources%20Manager">Human Resources Manager</a> (1974).
Early political career (1971–1995).
Early year.
Muhyiddin's involvement in politics began when he joined <a href="UMNO">UMNO</a> as an ordinary member at the Muar Dalam division in 1971. He was elected as <a href="UMNO">UMNO</a> youth chief of the Pagoh division and the secretary in 1976. Later he became Youth Chief of Johor state <a href="UMNO">UMNO</a> Youth until 1987.
Muhyiddin occupied the seats of Exco in the national Malaysia UMNO Youth. In 1984, Muhyiddin was elected the UMNO division chief of Pagoh, replacing <a href="Othman%20Saat">Othman Saat</a>. Muhyiddin rose the ranks and file of Johor UMNO quickly. From being a state executive council member, he rose to become <a href="Johor">Johor</a> UMNO's head and later became Menteri Besar of Johor.
Muhyiddin contested and was elected Member of Parliament for the <a href="Pagoh%20%28federal%20constituency%29">Pagoh constituency</a> in the 1978 general election and kept the seat until 1982. Muhyiddin was appointed Parliamentary Secretary in the Ministry for Foreign Affairs; subsequently, he was promoted to Deputy Minister in the Ministry of Federal Territories and later the Ministry of Trade and Industry. 
In 1984, Muhyiddin contested a UMNO Supreme Council seat but lost. Muhyiddin was later appointed the UMNO Johor state liaison chairman and next appointed a Supreme Council member. In November 1990, he was a candidate for the UMNO vice-presidency but lost again. He attempted again in the November 1993 UMNO party election, successfully this time.
Menteri Besar of Johor.
In the 1986 general election, Muhyiddin contested and won the <a href="Johor%20State%20Legislative%20Assembly">Johor State Legislative</a> constituency seat of Bukit Serampang, opening the path for him to become the <a href="Menteri%20Besar%20of%20Johor">Menteri Besar of Johor</a> on 13 August 1986.
His tenure as Menteri Besar lasted until 6 May 1995.
Rise to prominence (1995–2009).
Muhyiddin returned to contest the <a href="Pagoh%20%28federal%20constituency%29">Pagoh parliamentary seat</a> in the <a href="1995%20Malaysian%20general%20election">1995 General Election</a>.
He served several different federal government cabinet posts as <a href="Minister%20of%20Youth%20and%20Sports%20%28Malaysia%29">Minister of Youth and Sports</a> (1995–1999), <a href="Minister%20of%20Domestic%20Trade%20and%20Consumer%20Affairs%20%28Malaysia%29">Minister of Domestic Trade and Consumer Affairs</a> (1999–2004), <a href="Minister%20of%20Agriculture%20and%20Agro-based%20Industry">Minister of Agriculture and Agro-based Industry</a> (2004–2008) and <a href="Minister%20of%20International%20Trade%20and%20Industry%20%28Malaysia%29">Minister of International Trade and Industry</a> (2008–2009). He was appointed <a href="Deputy%20Prime%20Minister%20of%20Malaysia">Deputy Prime Minister</a> and <a href="Minister%20of%20Education%20%28Malaysia%29">Minister of Education</a> by Prime Minister <a href="Najib%20Razak">Najib Razak</a> in 2009.
He lost the 1996 election when defending the vice-president post. Eventually, in the election in 2000, he again won the post of vice-president of UMNO, remaining in that post until the October 2008 party election, when Muhyiddin successfully sought the higher post of deputy president, which was left vacant as the incumbent, Najib Razak (who was acting party president after the retirement of <a href="Abdullah%20Ahmad%20Badawi">Abdullah Ahmad Badawi</a>), became UMNO president.
2009 UMNO General Assembly and party election.
Muhyiddin attacked <a href="Abdullah%20Ahmad%20Badawi">Abdullah Ahmad Badawi</a>'s original transition plan as "too long", and some people say that at one point, Muhyiddin was about to ask and force Abdullah to quit, though he never did so directly. During the 2008 general election, Muhyiddin managed to keep his seat and remained as an UMNO leader. Shocked by the election results, he called for reforms.
During the 2009 UMNO General Assembly and party election, Muhyiddin was a candidate for the deputy president post, which was vacated by the incoming prime minister <a href="Najib%20Tun%20Razak">Najib Tun Razak</a>. He was challenged by <a href="Mohd%20Ali%20Rustam">Mohd Ali Rustam</a>, Malacca chief minister, and <a href="Muhammad%20Muhammad%20Taib">Muhammad Muhammad Taib</a>, Rural and Regional Development Minister. Muhyiddin, seen as a supporter of <a href="Mahathir%20Mohamad">Mahathir Mohamad</a>, was seen to be the front-runner for the race, garnering many nominations by the UMNO divisions. Nevertheless, the competition was tough, as Taib and Rustam gained more ground, especially from the Badawi camp. Political analysts tipped the race to be very tight. However, the UMNO supreme council decided to disqualify Ali Rustam's candidacy after his assistants were caught involved with corruption after an investigation. The election resulted in Muhyiddin's election to the post with 1,575 votes to Muhammad Taib's 916.
Deputy premiership (2009–2015).
Muhyiddin was appointed deputy prime minister on 9 April 2009, when Najib took over from Abdullah Ahmad Badawi and unveiled his <a href="First%20Najib%20cabinet">first Cabinet</a>.
Continuing as <a href="Minister%20of%20Education%20%28Malaysia%29">Minister for Education</a>, he announced the decision to return to the teaching of mathematics and science in Malay in all government primary and secondary schools.
Muhyiddin waded into controversy in March 2010 by stating he was "<a href="Ketuanan%20Melayu">Malay first</a>" rather than "<a href="Malaysian%20Malaysia">Malaysian first</a>". He also said that there is nothing wrong with other races doing the same; for example, the Chinese could claim themselves to be "<a href="Malaysian%20Chinese">Chinese</a> first, <a href="Malaysians">Malaysian</a> second" and same for the <a href="Malaysian%20Indians">Indians</a>. On 13 July 2010, he said that anyone was free to form an association, including Chinese or Indian versions of the Malay rights group <a href="Perkasa">Perkasa</a>. Prime Minister Najib came to Muhyiddin's defence, denying that his statement was inconsistent with the "<a href="1Malaysia">1Malaysia</a>" concept promoted by the government.
Sacked from the cabinet.
During Najib's mid-term Cabinet reshuffle on 28 July 2015, he was dropped from his position as Deputy Prime Minister. The dismissal came after Muhyiddin had made public and critical remarks about Najib's handling of the <a href="1Malaysia%20Development%20Berhad%20scandal">1Malaysia Development Berhad scandal</a>. Najib stated that Muhyiddin's dismissal, and the contemporaneous dismissals of other Ministers who had been critical of his leadership, was to create a more "unified team". Muhyiddin remained UMNO deputy president, but after keeping up criticism of UMNO, he was eventually sacked by the party's supreme council in June 2016. Muhyiddin remained unrepentant, maintaining that he had never betrayed the party and pledging to continue speaking out.
Post deputy premiership (2015–2020).
Establishment of BERSATU party.
In August 2016, Muhyiddin registered a new political party, called <a href="Parti%20Pribumi%20Bersatu%20Malaysia">Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia</a> (PPBM or Bersatu for short) together with former Malaysian prime minister <a href="Mahathir%20Mohamad">Mahathir Mohamad</a>. Muhyiddin became the party's president while Mahathir and his son Mukhriz became the chairman and deputy president. The new party is focused on Bumiputera – <a href="Malays%20%28ethnic%20group%29">Malays</a> and <a href="Orang%20Asli">Orang Asli</a> – in the sense that full membership is only open to Bumiputera. Other races can join the party but cannot vote or contest in party elections.
Minister of Home Affairs.
He was appointed as <a href="Minister%20of%20Home%20Affairs%20%28Malaysia%29">Malaysian Minister of Home Affairs</a> by Prime Minister Tun Dr. <a href="Mahathir%20Mohamad">Mahathir Mohamad</a> when <a href="Pakatan%20Harapan">Pakatan Harapan</a> won the 14th General Election.
Prime Minister (2020–2021).
On 29 February 2020, a week after the country was thrown into a <a href="2020%20Malaysian%20political%20crisis">political crisis</a>, Muhyiddin was appointed <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Malaysia">Prime Minister</a> by the <a href="Yang%20Di-Pertuan%20Agong">King of Malaysia</a>, following the abrupt resignation of <a href="Mahathir%20Mohamad">Mahathir Mohamad</a> five days before. He is the first person appointed to the position while holding both a parliamentary and state seat at the same time.
COVID-19 pandemic and movement control order.
During his administration, <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20Malaysia">COVID-19</a> spread throughout the nation. In response, Muhyiddin implemented the <a href="Malaysian%20movement%20control%20order">Movement Control Order</a> (MCO) on 16 March 2020 to prevent the disease from infecting more Malaysians. The MCO started nationwide from 18 March and was extended conditionally to 9 June 2020. In response to the economic impact of COVID-19, he introduced an economic stimulus package worth RM 250 billion on 27 March to soften the economic strain during the MCO.
On 1 May, in conjunction with Labour Day, Muhyiddin announced a Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO). Certain economic sectors were allowed to operate gradually as long as SOP are followed. Travel restrictions are partially lifted to allow stranded students staying on their campuses and people who are stuck in other states to return to their respective home. Sports, recreational, and large gatherings are still prohibited under the CMCO.
On 10 May, it was announced that the CMCO will last for another four weeks until 9 June. More sectors will be allowed to operate and fewer restrictions are to be applied. Shopping malls, dine-in and non-contact sports are allowed as long as social distancing is observed.
The CMCO was converted into Recovery Movement Control Order (RMCO) and ran from 10 June until 31 August. Under the RMCO, more restrictions will be relaxed to allow the public to carry out their daily activities while complying with standard operating procedures. Almost all social, religious, business, and educational activities are allowed to resume. Hair salons, morning and night markets, and sports-related businesses like gymnasiums will open on a staggered basis, as well as religious congregation such as prayers as long as strict SOPs are followed. Reflexology centres, nightclubs, theme parks, karaoke centres, and gatherings such as kenduri (feasts) are still barred during the RMCO.
The government's COVID-19 response had a 93% approval rating in September 2020, with 69% approval for Muhyiddin himself.
Until early September 2020, Malaysia had a low number of COVID-19 cases. Infections rose following the <a href="2020%20Sabah%20state%20election">2020 Sabah state election</a> in September, leading to a surge in <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20Sabah">Sabah</a> which spread to the <a href="Klang%20Valley">Klang Valley</a> area. However, unlike the initial promise to reinstate the Movement Control Order (MCO) if the case returns to 3 digits, the government only imposed the Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO) under the name of "economy". The government did not impose the MCO until January 2021. Nevertheless, the "MCO 2.0", was criticised for being not as strict as the "MCO 1.0" from March to May 2020.
The government's mismanagement of the second and third waves provoked widespread anger among Malaysians, such as hashtags like "#KerajaanGagal" (means Failed Government) and/or "#MuhyiddinOut" which trended online. During the third wave in the mid 2021, a "Black Flag Campaign ("Bendera Hitam")" became a trend, urging Muhyiddin to immediately resign.
On July 31, 2021, hundreds of <a href="Protests%20over%20responses%20to%20the%20COVID-19%20pandemic%23Malaysia">protesters gathered in Kuala Lumpur</a> calling for Muhyiddin's resignation over his government's response to the pandemic.
Myanmar.
After a bilateral meeting, Muhyiddin and Indonesian President <a href="Joko%20Widodo">Joko Widodo</a> called for a special meeting of <a href="ASEAN">ASEAN</a> on <a href="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> after the <a href="2021%20Myanmar%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">2021 coup d'état</a>. After the April 2021 meeting, where representatives from the deposed <a href="National%20League%20for%20Democracy">National League for Democracy</a> did not attend, Muhyiddin announced that Malaysia's three proposals to <a href="Min%20Aung%20Hlaing">Min Aung Hlaing</a> were not rejected, including calls to end violence against civilians during the <a href="2021%20Burmese%20protests">2021 Burmese protests</a>, release of political detainees, and allow the Chair of ASEAN access to Myanmar.
Proclamation of emergency.
On 19 October 2020, the <a href="Yang%20di-Pertuan%20Agong">Yang di-Pertuan Agong</a> Sultan <a href="Abdullah%20of%20Pahang">Abdullah of Pahang</a> rejected Muhyiddin's request for him to issue a <a href="state%20of%20emergency">proclamation of emergency</a> in response to a spike in COVID-19 cases throughout the country. However, on 21 January 2021, a new request to issue a <a href="2021%20Malaysian%20state%20of%20emergency">proclamation of emergency</a> was granted by the <a href="Yang%20di-Pertuan%20Agong">Yang di-Pertuan Agong</a>, and is expected to last until 1 August. <a href="Parliament%20of%20Malaysia">Parliament</a> and all <a href="Elections%20in%20Malaysia">elections</a> were suspended while the proclamation is in effect.
Loss of majority support and resignation.
On 8 July 2021, <a href="United%20Malays%20National%20Organisation">UMNO</a> withdrew support for Muhyiddin and called for his resignation in July 2021 over the handling of the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20Malaysia">COVID-19 pandemic</a>. As well as a failure to prevent a record rise in COVID-19 infections and deaths, UMNO President <a href="Ahmad%20Zahid%20Hamidi">Ahmad Zahid Hamidi</a> cited the management of the <a href="Economic%20impact%20of%20the%20COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20Malaysia">severe economic impact</a>, lack of <a href="Impact%20of%20the%20COVID-19%20pandemic%20on%20politics%20in%20Malaysia">political stability</a> and extension of the <a href="Malaysian%20movement%20control%20order">Movement Control Order</a> in his call for Muhyiddin to make way for a new interim premier.
On 4 August 2021, Putrajaya, Muhyiddin Yassin submitted a motion of confidence to the <a href="Yang%20di%20Pertuan%20Agong">Yang di Pertuan Agong</a> of Malaysia stating that he had received numerous declarations which provided that he still had the majority support within the lower house of parliament <a href="Dewan%20Rakyat">Dewan Rakyat</a>. Therefore, the action of resignation under <a href="Federal%20Constitution%20of%20Malaysia">Federal Constitution of Malaysia</a> under section 43(4) isn't valid nor legal. He stated that the <a href="motion%20of%20no%20confidence">motion of no confidence</a> will take place in September if the parliament has doubts of his ruling. However, this statement has been rejected by opposition leader <a href="Anwar%20Ibrahim">Anwar Ibrahim</a> who claims that 112 or more MPs have rejected <a href="Perikatan%20Nasional">Perikatan Nasional</a>. Therefore, <a href="Anwar%20Ibrahim">Anwar Ibrahim</a>'s statement concludes that Muyhiddin claims isn't valid and potentially fraudulent.
Following <a href="Anwar%20Ibrahim">Anwar Ibrahim</a>'s statement, on 6 August 2021, Muhyiddin had stated during a press conference in <a href="Pagoh">Pagoh, Johor</a> that is he is still confident that he still holds majority support within the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Malaysia">Parliament</a>.
On 15 August 2021, <a href="Mohd%20Redzuan%20Md%20Yusof">Mohd Redzuan Md Yusof</a>, the <a href="Minister%20in%20the%20Prime%20Minister%27s%20Department">Minister in the Prime Minister's Department (Special Functions)</a>, stated that Muhyiddin would resign on the next day. Muhyiddin and his cabinet submitted their resignation to <a href="Yang%20di-Pertuan%20Agong">the king</a> on Monday, 16 August 2021.
Post-premiership (2021–present).
Chairman of the National Recovery Council.
On 27 August 2021, 9th and newly minted Prime Minister <a href="Ismail%20Sabri%20Yaakob">Ismail Sabri Yaakob</a> announced his new <a href="Ismail%20Sabri%20cabinet">Cabinet</a> line-up, which did not include Muhyiddin, contradicting rumors that Muhyiddin would be appointed Senior Minister, a position akin to the position held by <a href="Lee%20Kuan%20Yew">Lee Kuan Yew</a>, the former <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Singapore">Prime Minister of Singapore</a> as <a href="Senior%20Minister%20of%20Singapore">Senior Minister</a>, after his premiership. On 4 September 2021, <a href="Chief%20Secretary%20to%20the%20Government">Chief Secretary to the Government</a> <a href="Mohd%20Zuki%20Ali">Mohd Zuki Ali</a> announced that Muhyiddin had been appointed as Chairman of the National Recovery Council (MPN), a Cabinet minister-level position and highest position in the important council in charge of the recovery efforts of the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20Malaysia">COVID-19 pandemic</a> based on confidence of the government in the ability of Muhyiddin in spearheading the COVID-19 pandemic recovery strategies. On 23 October 2021, he and his wife received the booster dose of COVID-19 vaccines.
Controversies and issues.
Alleged misuse of RMAF helicopter.
Muhyiddin, as the Deputy Prime Minister, has used a <a href="Royal%20Malaysian%20Air%20Force">RMAF</a> Nuri <a href="helicopter">helicopter</a> to attend and open <a href="UMNO">UMNO</a>'s divisional assembly in the interior of <a href="Sabah">Sabah</a>, which has nothing to do with his official duties. His actions have been strongly criticized by the federal opposition led by <a href="Lim%20Kit%20Siang">Lim Kit Siang</a> as it was a misuse of his powers as Deputy Prime Minister. Lim even questioned whether the <a href="Malaysian%20Anti-Corruption%20Commission">Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission</a> (MACC) would investigate Muhyiddin, as MACC has been conducting various investigations into assemblymen in states controlled by Lim's <a href="Pakatan%20Rakyat">Pakatan Rakyat</a>.
Racial views.
On 31 March 2010, Muhyiddin attracted controversy by declaring himself as a "<a href="Ketuanan%20Melayu">Malay first</a>" rather than a "<a href="Malaysian%20Malaysia">Malaysian first</a>" when responding to <a href="Democratic%20Action%20Party">Democratic Action Party</a> (DAP) leader <a href="Lim%20Kit%20Siang">Lim Kit Siang</a>'s challenge in the parliament for him to state whether he is a Malay or a Malaysian first. However, Muhyiddin retorted although he is Malay first, that doesn't mean he being Malay is not Malaysian. The Prime Minister <a href="Najib%20Razak">Najib Razak</a> defended Muhyiddin's "Malay first, Malaysian second" assertion and controversial statement even though it contradicts the <a href="1Malaysia">1Malaysia</a> concept which talks of "a nation where, it is hoped, every Malaysian perceives himself or herself as Malaysian first, and by race, religion, geographical region or socio-economic background second".
Muhyiddin attracted criticism again on 12 April 2010 by calling the members of a new inter-faith committee 'small fry', causing strong reaction from the public and uproar from the <a href="Malaysian%20Consultative%20Council%20of%20Buddhism%2C%20Christianity%2C%20Hinduism%2C%20Sikhism%20and%20Taoism">Malaysian Consultative Council of Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Sikhism and Taoism</a> (MCCBCHST) to back off from joining the committee for the time being. Muhyiddin was quick to deny he ever say that and stated he was misquoted. Muhyiddin later doubled down and uttered 'Yes, I am Malay first and no apologies'.
Legal name dispute.
In April 2021, the Shah Alam court has reversed a preventive detention order signed by him during his time as the Minister of Home Affairs because he signed the order using his unofficial name, Muhyiddin bin Mohd. Yassin instead of his <a href="legal%20name">legal name</a>/<a href="birth%20name">birth name</a>, Mahiaddin bin Md. Yasin.
Personal life.
Family.
He married <a href="Noorainee%20Abdul%20Rahman">Noorainee Abdul Rahman</a> in 1972 and has 4 children; 2 sons and 2 daughters, namely Fakhri Yassin Mahiaddin, Nabilah Mahiaddin, and Farhan Yassin Mahiaddin respectively. All of his children are heavily involved in business and corporate, entertainment or writing industries. His son, Fakhri Yassin, was a corporate figure in Malaysia and assumed the position of Executive Chairman. The second child, Nabilah was involved in book writing while Najwa and Farhan Yassin shared the same interest in the entertainment industry.
Sport.
He is an avid golf lover.
Health issues.
In the aftermath of <a href="2018%20Malaysian%20general%20election">2018 general election</a> (GE14), Muhyiddin was diagnosed with an early-stage tumour in the <a href="pancreas">pancreas</a>. He had spent one month in <a href="Mount%20Elizabeth%20Hospital">Mount Elizabeth Hospital</a>, Singapore from July to August 2018, during which he underwent a surgery to extract the tumour. The operation was successful and he returned to Malaysia in stable condition. He was scheduled for a series of follow-up <a href="chemotherapy">chemotherapy</a> treatment after <a href="Eid%20al-Adha">Hari Raya Haji</a>, for up to six months. He told reporters at the Parliament, "for cancer cases such as this, it is normal to go through follow-up treatment including chemotherapy for 12 rounds over the duration of six months."
Based on medical advice, Muhyiddin took a one-month medical leave to recover post-surgery. Prime Minister <a href="Mahathir%20Mohamad">Mahathir Mohamad</a> took charge of the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Home%20Affairs%20%28Malaysia%29">Ministry of Home Affairs</a> during Muhyiddin's absence.
On 22 May 2020, Muhyiddin entered into a 14-day quarantine after an officer who attended the post-Cabinet meeting at the Prime Minister's Office on 21 May tested positive for COVID-19. On 4 June 2020, he completed the 14-day quarantine period and was tested negative for <a href="COVID-19">COVID-19</a>. Therefore, he was allowed to return to the workplace to discharge his official duties as Prime Minister.
